item.title: In Ukraine Crisis, the Looming Threat of a New Cold War
item.description: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the front lines in eastern Ukraine, which is seen as a likely flashpoint in a broader war.

item.title: Highgate Cemetery: A City of the Dead That Inspires the Living
item.description: Highgate Cemetery is the final resting place for about 170,000 Londoners, among them the famous, the infamous and the ordinary. Since the start of the pandemic, its leafy pathways have taken on new meaning for some in the city.

item.title: Putin’s Baseless Claims of Genocide Hint at More Than War
item.description: The invocations serve to justify not just Moscow’s actions in Ukraine, but also its wider quest for a new imperial identity rooted in Russian ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a virtual Security Council meeting on Friday. Analysts and the West say his use of certain language may indicate a prelude to invasion.

item.title: Ex-Modeling Agent and Epstein Associate Found Dead in a Paris Jail
item.description: Jean-Luc Brunel had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young girls for Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Sante prison in Paris where Jean-Luc Brunel was being held.

item.title: Lukashenko Once Kept Russia at a Distance. Now He Is a Docile Putin Satrap.
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus once skillfully managed Moscow, but now he is doing the Kremlin’s bidding in Russia’s confrontation with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus attending joint military exercises between Russia and Belarus on Thursday near Asipovichy, Belarus.

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Put Sanctions on Russia Now, Zelensky Urges West
item.description: “What are you waiting for?” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine asked Western leaders in Munich, as Russian-backed rebels urged people to evacuate and shelling escalated in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Why Ukraine Matters: What to Know About the Crisis With Russia
item.description: Here’s how the country ended up at the center of a global crisis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier this month in Luhansk Oblast, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: As Gale Made an Extreme Sport of Heathrow Landings, He Called the Plays
item.description: Jerry Dyer became a media sensation after filming, and commenting on, planes landing at the London airport during a howling storm.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Canada Protests: Police Clamp Down on Ottawa Demonstrators
item.description: A swell of police officers and heavy tow trucks closed in on the encampment of truckers on Friday after three weeks of demonstrations had roiled the capital and other parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers beginning to clear the trucker blockade in Ottawa on Friday.

item.title: How Putin Has Already Weakened Ukraine’s Economy
item.description: Flights have been canceled, commercial shipping is threatened, and people fear an invasion is not far off.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Odessa, Ukraine, on Thursday. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has succeeded in destabilizing Ukraine and making clear that Russia could wreck the country’s economy.

item.title: As Shelling Picks Up, Eastern Ukrainians Are Cowering
item.description: With nowhere to go, many are increasingly fearful that their villages could become the flash point for a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentina Melnichenko, 72, in her backyard on Friday, a day after it had been hit by artillery in Vrubivka, Ukraine.

item.title: How Macron Stands as France's Presidential Election Looms
item.description: The president, not even a formal candidate yet, seems to benefit from standing above the anti-immigrant fray.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron last month. He is leading in the polls and is the favorite, even though he has not officially declared his candidacy.

item.title: Young Boy Dies in Afghanistan After Being Trapped in a Well
item.description: The boy, Haidar Jan, who was thought to be 5, fell into a roughly 85-foot-deep well on Tuesday in a village near Qalat, the capital of Zabul Province.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:description: Rescuers were at work on Thursday in the southern village of Shokak in Zabul Province.

item.title: Hundreds Rescued From Burning Ferry Near Greek Island
item.description: A fire broke out on the deck of the ferry, which was taking 239 passengers to Italy from Greece. Two of them were trapped, and at least 11 were missing.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A ferry between Greece and Italy caught fire on Friday near the island of Corfu.

item.title: Shelling escalates in eastern Ukraine, as U.S. officials warn of pretexts for a Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees board buses in Avilo-Upsenka, Russia, after fleeing a separatist-held area of eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Counting Russian troops is an imprecise science.
item.description: American officials said a new troop estimate includes some forces that were not previously counted — most notably Russian forces in Crimea, as well as separatist forces in the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A tactical exercise last month in the Rostov region of Russia, near Ukraine’s border.

item.title: A Press Tour Turns Frantic in Ukraine As Russia-Backed Shelling Intensifies
item.description: As shelling intensified in eastern Ukraine, a seemingly routine press tour turned into a frantic rush to safety.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops in Luhansk Oblast, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday, a day after mortar attacks continued through the night.

item.title: Storm Eunice Kills at Least 8
item.description: Gusts toppled trees and sent debris flying, leaving tens of thousands without power and disrupting travel a day later.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Strong winds affected waves in Porthcawl, Wales, on Friday.

item.title: The Search Has Begun for an Antarctic Pioneer’s Lost Ship
item.description: Explorers have started combing the Weddell Sea for one of the most revered ships in the history of polar exploration, Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance, which sank in 1915.
item.dc:creator: Esther Horvath and Henry Fountain

item.title: U.S. Lifts Temporary Ban on Avocados From Mexico
item.description: The ban was issued last week after a U.S. inspector was verbally threatened in the state of Michoacán in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Workers at an avocado packing plant in Uruapan in the Mexican state of Michoacán on Wednesday.

item.title: Soaring Energy Bills Deepen Crisis for Turks, and Erdogan
item.description: Hit by spiraling inflation, electricity bills have doubled for households and businesses in only a month.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A bar in Istanbul on Wednesday. The cost of power has doubled in some parts of Turkey, fueling widespread discontent.

item.title: Conflict and Climate Change Ravage Syria’s Agricultural Heartland
item.description: Drought and a decade of war have brought failing crops and poverty to a region once known as Syria’s breadbasket. Even the bread has changed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers in northeast Syria say their sheep are thinner, less healthy and selling for much less.

item.title: Shelling Escalates in Ukraine, as Thousands Flee Fearing Attack
item.description: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: At the front line on Saturday in Krymske, Ukraine, where a building was damaged by mortar fire overnight.

item.title: Police in Ottawa Rout Truckers With a Show of Force
item.description: A central area of the protest that roiled Canada’s capital for three weeks was cleared of demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers clearing protestors in Ottawa on Saturday.

item.title: Intense shelling rocks eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian man ducks for cover during incoming artillery fire near the front line between Ukraine and Russia-backed separatists near Svitlodarsk on Saturday.

item.title: How Life Resumes
item.description: We can wait for normal life to return, or we can just start living.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Kamala Harris Says West Faces ‘Defining Moment’ Over Ukraine
item.description: The vice president’s first public remarks on the Ukraine crisis were watched with scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Paramilitaries Prepare for Conflict With Russia.
item.description: Times journalists followed the members of one such group
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: Fears grow in eastern Ukraine as shelling picks up in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: An Earlier Trek to Ottawa Had a Different Tone but Still Captured the Nation
item.description: Deep in the Great Depression, about 1,000 men attempted to reach Ottawa to reform relief programs. Most didn’t make it but they eventually achieved their aims.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A swell of police officers closed in on the encampment of truckers on Friday.

item.title: When Architects Made Worlds
item.description: MoMA explores an era of sweeping change, when South Asian architects — pioneering women, among them — redefined the postcolonial era and helped construct new nation states.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.category: The Project of Independence: Architectures of Decolonization in South Asia, 1947-1985 (Exhibit)

item.title: Zelensky leaves Ukraine, heading to Munich to rally Western support.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, front right, attending a military drill in northern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: President Zelensky asks the West to make no deals ‘behind our back’ as the threat to Ukraine grows.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front line position in Krymsk, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: As warnings of war grow louder, Ukrainians try to keep their bearings.
item.description: The crisis has taken a toll on many Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on Friday in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine, near a crater left by shelling. A conflict with separatists has been under way there for years.

item.title: Biden Says Putin Has Chosen ‘Catastrophic’ War Over Diplomacy
item.description: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the Roosevelt Room in Washington, D.C. on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Surgeon General and Family Have Covid
item.description: The doctor and his wife tested positive after caring for their two sick children.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, at the White House in July. “When you’ve been as safe as you can, getting Covid-19 can be frustrating and disappointing,” he said on Friday.

item.title: Videos show reported explosions near Luhansk.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Brenna Smith, Haley Willis and Masha Froliak

item.title: What videos show about disputed claims in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Brenna Smith and Masha Froliak

item.title: Hong Kong Delays an Election Amid a Covid Surge
item.description: Carrie Lam, the chief executive, said the vote would be postponed until May 8.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Carrie Lam, Hong Kong's chief executive, announced on Friday that the city would postpone choosing a new leader until May as it struggles to tackle a wave of coronavirus infections.

item.title: A Timeline of the Tensions Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Here is a look at some key moments leading to Russia’s troop buildup around Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a front line position in Schastia, eastern Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Biden says the U.S. believes Putin has decided to invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the Roosevelt Room in Washington, D.C. on Friday.

item.title: Kazakhstan's Internet Shutdowns Could Be a Warning for Ukraine
item.description: Control of the internet is increasingly part of any modern conflict.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker cleaning out a market that had been set on fire and ransacked after protests broke out in Almaty, Kazakhstan, in January.

item.title: What to Know About Boosters and Vaccine Restrictions for International Travel
item.description: The requirements for entering foreign countries during the pandemic can be confusing and ever-changing, especially when it comes to boosters. Here’s what to expect.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: A passenger presents proof of vaccination at the Henri Coandă International Airport in Romania.

item.title: The U.S. Increases Vaccine Aid to 11 African Countries
item.description: The U.S. government said it would provide “intensive financial, technical and diplomatic support” to African countries that have recently shown the capacity to hasten vaccine uptake.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: Receiving Covid-19 vaccinations at a health center in Kampala, Uganda, last week.

item.title: Red Covid, an Update
item.description: The partisan gap in Covid deaths is still growing, but more slowly.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barnegat Light, N.J.

item.title: Russia sends mixed signals as tensions rise.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers assessing the damage after a kindergarten in Stanitsa Luhanska was hit by shelling on Thursday.

item.title: Storm Eunice Slams Northern Europe With Dangerously High Winds
item.description: A 122-mile-per-hour gust was recorded in England, where one weather official said the storm would be the worst the country had seen in 30 years. At least seven deaths were reported.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The roof of the O2 Arena in London was damaged by high winds on Friday.

item.title: Vladimir Putin: Crafty Strategist or Aggrieved and Reckless Leader?
item.description: Analysts puzzling over the Russian leader’s intentions say that his troop buildup around Ukraine could be a convincing bluff, but also posit that he could have fundamentally changed during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia marked the 78th anniversary last month of the end of the Leningrad Siege in St. Petersburg.

item.title: South Korea Prepares for Another Covid-Era National Election
item.description: The government requires people with Covid to remain in isolation at home, but a special time window on Election Day would allow them to leave to cast their ballots.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Waiting in line to be tested for the coronavirus in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: China's Fast Train, an Olympic Highlight
item.description: A journey by high-speed train offers a window on the nation’s future, as well as some of the past it would like to leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and James Hill

item.title: Why China Doesn’t Have an mRNA Vaccine for Covid
item.description: Beijing once said it had two mRNA shots within reach and ready for approval — one homemade and one produced by a foreign company. Today, neither is available.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: A Covid testing site in January in Beijing. China’s “zero-Covid” strategy has kept case numbers down, but the country still lacks an mRNA vaccine.

item.title: Australia Reopens to International Travelers
item.description: For nearly two years, the country projected a harsh message of rigidity and “rules are rules.” Will long-haul travelers bet on the easygoing, inviting image it is sending out now?
item.dc:creator: Tacey Rychter and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: International travelers will be able to visit spots like the Opera Bar in Sydney starting Feb. 21.
